title: For Whom the Sleigh Bell Tolls
text:
"For Whom the Sleigh Bell Tolls" is the eighth episode of the <a href="American%20Dad%21%20%28season%206%29">season</a> of "<a href="American%20Dad%21">American Dad!</a>". It originally aired on <a href="Fox%20Broadcasting%20Company">Fox</a> in the United States on December 12, 2010. The episode follows the events caused by <a href="Stan%20Smith%20%28American%20Dad%21%29">Stan Smith</a>, as he gives his son <a href="Steve%20Smith%20%28American%20Dad%21%29">Steve</a> a rifle for Christmas, even though his wife <a href="Francine%20Smith">Francine</a> forbade him to. When Steve is practicing shooting, he accidentally kills a <a href="mall%20Santa">mall Santa</a>. The family decides to bury the body in the woods, but it then turns out that it was the real Santa, who wants revenge by killing the Smiths.
The episode was written by Erik Durbin and directed by Bob Bowen. It was slightly modeled after the film "<a href="300%20%28film%29">300</a>", and was first announced at the <a href="San%20Diego%20Comic-Con%20International">San Diego Comic-Con International</a> in July 2010. It is the fourth "American Dad!" Christmas special, following in the footsteps of "<a href="The%20Best%20Christmas%20Story%20Never%20Told">The Best Christmas Story Never Told</a>", "<a href="The%20Most%20Adequate%20Christmas%20Ever">The Most Adequate Christmas Ever</a>" and "<a href="Rapture%27s%20Delight">Rapture's Delight</a>."
The episode was met with mixed reviews from critics, with some of them praising its bloody themes, while others dismissed it for being crude and unoriginal. According to the <a href="Nielsen%20ratings">Nielsen ratings</a>, it was viewed by 6.26 million viewers in its original airing. The episode featured guest performances by <a href="Clancy%20Brown">Clancy Brown</a> and <a href="Jeff%20Fischer%20%28actor%29">Jeff Fischer</a>, along with several recurring guest voice actors for the series. The episode features the song "<a href="Carol%20of%20the%20Bells">Carol of the Bells</a>" as performed by Pennsylvania metalcore band <a href="August%20Burns%20Red">August Burns Red</a> as its main theme.
Plot.
<a href="Stan%20Smith%20%28American%20Dad%21%29">Stan</a> continues to reject the idea that <a href="List%20of%20American%20Dad%21%20characters%23Main%20household">Jeff Fischer</a> is now a member of the family despite <a href="Francine%20Smith%20%28American%20Dad%21%29">Francine</a>'s suggestion that he should be included in their family traditions. Despite Francine's objections, Stan gives <a href="Steve%20Smith%20%28American%20Dad%21%29">Steve</a> an <a href="AK-47">AK-47</a> assault rifle for Christmas and Steve accidentally shoots a <a href="mall%20Santa">mall Santa</a>. Steve, in turn, is shattered emotionally and swears never to pick up a weapon again. Meanwhile, <a href="Roger%20%28American%20Dad%21%29">Roger</a> goes off in search of the strongest <a href="whiskey">whiskey</a> possible after having trouble getting drunk, and he is directed to a hillbilly <a href="moonshine">moonshine</a>r in the Chimdale Mountains, named Bob Todd, who teaches him his ways.
Stan convinces Steve to hide the body from Francine and try to find out who the Santa was with his fingerprint, but his DNA is not in the <a href="Central%20Intelligence%20Agency">CIA</a> database. Stan dismisses this and doesn't investigate further. Francine quickly discovers the body, and as the family buries the body; she chastises them for not letting her cut off the hands and smash the teeth out; much to their chagrin. The next day they receive threatening letters, stating that someone knows what they did and that they will be punished. They watch the news and discover that no one really feels like it is Christmas, as if someone killed Santa. Feeling doubtful, they then dig up the body and discover it is gone. An <a href="elf">elf</a> appears and tells them that it was actually the real Santa that they buried, and that he is recovering and rejuvenating in a <a href="Star%20Wars">Star Wars</a> Bacta Tank at the North Pole. Santa vows vengeance on the Smiths, so they decide to take refuge with Roger in Bob Todd's cabin.
Jeff arrives to spend the holiday with <a href="Hayley%20Smith%20%28American%20Dad%21%29">Hayley</a>, much to Stan's displeasure. However, Santa soon arrives since Jeff wrote a letter telling him where they would be staying. Bob Todd reveals that his airplane-house is also an armory, which includes an M60 machine gun, two <a href="RPK">RPK</a>s and an <a href="M16%20rifle">M16</a> assault rifle, to fend off an attack of endless waves of armed elves, flying reindeer, and an enormous snowman (reminiscent of a Cave Troll from "<a href="Lord%20of%20the%20Rings">Lord of the Rings</a>") led by Santa. Francine snaps Steve out of his fears, ordering him to "pick up a gun this instant and send these toy makers to Hell!" and the family proceeds to defend themselves. Santa tries to convince Jeff to abandon the Smiths, recognizing that he was not involved in their plot to hide his body, and by offering a <a href="relic">relic</a> from <a href="The%20Golden%20Compass">The Golden Compass</a>. Jeff walks to Santa's side, but then turns on him and is able to pull Stan who was injured to safety. While Jeff takes care of Stan, Jeff says he thinks Stan is "an ass", but the two agree on their love for Hayley, causing Stan to see Jeff as a true member of the family. The family is almost overrun, until Santa and his army are forced to retreat because they only had until Christmas morning to get vengeance. As Bob Todd gathers reindeer meat for food and sex, Santa disappears, leaving behind a letter warning them that he will return next year to take his revenge and kill them, while the Smith family realizes that they have found a new Christmas tradition.
Production.
"For Whom the Sleigh Bell Tolls" was written by series regular Erik Durbin and directed by series regular Bob Bowen. The episode was the twenty-second to be produced in the season five production cycle. The first few minutes of the episode were previewed at the <a href="San%20Diego%20Comic-Con%20International">San Diego Comic-Con International</a> in July 2010, but shown in <a href="black-and-white">black-and-white</a> form. While writing the episode, the writers tried to come up with a bloody story. Writer Durbin said, "Everybody in the [writing] room kind of was talking about making it as bloody as possible, I think. It was just which movie were we going to model it after. [...] I think ‘<a href="300%20%28film%29">300</a>’ got thrown around the most, talking about trying to make it as bloody and cool as ‘300.’" The episode had a <a href="TV-14">TV-14</a> rating, and series co-creator <a href="Seth%20MacFarlane">Seth MacFarlane</a> said that "no kids will ever see it", joking that "They follow those [content ratings] like the f-ing Bible." He also said that the episode informs kids that "Santa really exists". He said, "Except that he’s a crazed murderer. But as long as the tradition is upheld, then I guess that’s all that’s important."
In August 2010, MacFarlane and the voice cast were present at the <a href="Television%20Critics%20Association">Television Critics Association</a> (TCA) press tour in Los Angeles, promoting the hundredth episode, "<a href="100%20A.D.%20%28American%20Dad%21%29">100 A.D.</a>" The event also included a table read of "For Whom the Sleigh Bell Tolls", and Gail Pennington of the "<a href="St.%20Louis%20Post-Dispatch">St. Louis Post-Dispatch</a>" wrote, "not much can really be said about the episode except that it includes a mass slaughter of elves." The event also previewed the animation for the final act of the episode. The band <a href="August%20Burns%20Red">August Burns Red</a>'s cover of "<a href="Carol%20of%20the%20Bells">Carol of the Bells</a>" was featured in the episode. Series regulars Matt McKenna and Erik Durbin provided the voice of Santa Claus and the moonshiner Bob Todd, respectively, while guest star <a href="Clancy%20Brown">Clancy Brown</a> provided the voice of the liquor store manager.
Cultural references.
The episode contains several pop culture references. The title of the episode "For Whom the Sleigh Bell Tolls" is a parody of the novel, <a href="For%20Whom%20the%20Bell%20Tolls">For Whom the Bell Tolls</a> and the <a href="Metallica">Metallica</a> song inspired by the novel. The action sequence and bloody themes were slightly modeled after the film "300". When Bob Todd is teaching Roger moonshining, Roger jumps over barrels of moonshine, similar to the "<a href="Donkey%20Kong">Donkey Kong</a>" video games. <a href="Frosty%20the%20Snowman%20%28TV%20program%29">Frosty the Snowman</a> appears in Santa's army, which is a reference to the <a href="Cave%20troll%23Peter%20Jackson.27s%20trilogy">cave-troll</a> scene in Moria from . The elves are wrangling Frosty in with a collar and chains almost exactly like the scene from Fellowship. When Jeff confronts Santa, he stabs him with the polar bear helmet from the film "<a href="The%20Golden%20Compass%20%28film%29">The Golden Compass</a>". When Santa arrives and finds them the song '<a href="Carol%20of%20the%20Bells">Carol of the Bells</a>' by <a href="August%20Burns%20Red">August Burns Red</a> plays. You can see GH-7 Medical droids from <a href="Star%20Wars">Star Wars</a> facilitating Santa's recuperation in a recovery tank, similar to the scene of <a href="Luke%20Skywalker">Luke Skywalker</a> recovering in the film <a href="The%20Empire%20Strikes%20Back">The Empire Strikes Back</a>.
Reception.
"For Whom the Sleigh Bell Tolls" was broadcast on December 12, 2010, as a part of an animated television night on Fox, and was preceded by an hour-long Christmas episode of creator and executive producer Seth MacFarlane's other show, "<a href="Family%20Guy">Family Guy</a>". It was viewed by 6.26 million viewers, according to the <a href="Nielsen%20ratings">Nielsen ratings</a>. The episode was up 18% in total viewership from the last episode. It also acquired a 3.1 rating in the 18–49 demographic, up 24% from the previous episode.
The episode was met with mixed reviews from critics. In a simultaneous review of the episodes of "<a href="The%20Simpsons">The Simpsons</a>" and "Family Guy" that preceded the show, Emily VanDerWerff of "<a href="The%20A.V.%20Club">The A.V. Club</a>" wrote, "American Dad always thrives at this time of year, since it plays perfectly into Stan's idea of patriotism and Americana as a kind of religion, but the too-lengthy action sequence killed any humorous momentum the episode had built up." She ultimately gave the episode a B rating, the second best of the night, behind the "Family Guy" episode "<a href="Road%20to%20the%20North%20Pole">Road to the North Pole</a>" and beating "The Simpsons" episode "<a href="Donnie%20Fatso">Donnie Fatso</a>". Jessica Russell of <a href="TV%20Guide%20%28Canada%29">TV Guide Canada</a> wrote that she was "already sick of holiday-themed episodes" due to their "feel-good, warm-and-fuzzy, family-oriented storylines." However, she praised the episode for being "anti-Christmas", saying, "that’s why I give props to Seth MacFarlane and his crude minions for pulling off the ultimate anti-Christmas episode in last night’s American Dad." In response to writer Durbin's goal to make it as "bloody and cool as "300"", Scott D. Pierce of "<a href="The%20Salt%20Lake%20Tribune">The Salt Lake Tribune</a>" wrote that it was "bloody", but not "cool". He called the episode "just derivative trash", and compared the episode's themes to the film "<a href="Bad%20Santa">Bad Santa</a>" and the evil <a href="List%20of%20recurring%20characters%20in%20Futurama%23Robot%20Santa">Robot Santa</a> from "<a href="Futurama">Futurama</a>". He concluded, saying, "as usual, "American Dad’s" Seth MacFarlane and his minions have done uninspired, unoriginal work that somehow mistakes crude for funny." Jason Hughes of <a href="TV%20Squad">TV Squad</a> was positive on the episode, and concluded saying, "[...] Santa will be back next year to try and finish the job. I wonder if MacFarlane will remember that little detail and give us a sequel?"
